channel.title: PC Under Attack?
channel.description:
Okay, so I was playing runescape when my client randomly crashed, just out of nowhere closed. I instantly reloaded a client and tried to login and couldn't for 15 minutes. I finally logged in noticed that the last connection wasn't my IP and all of my possessions were gone, but not long after I logged in my client crashed again.
By this time, I knew something pretty bad was going on. But wait, it gets better..
I opened my Task Manager to see if there were any suspicious processes and I couldn't find a thing, while looking at my processes, they just all started to end. If I opened a program it would close. It was like someone had total control of my PC and I had hardly any other than opening programs that would be instantly closed until my PC turned off.
So, I hopped straight onto another PC to see if I could figure anything out about what may have happened and I'm clueless. So, could anyone please tell me what has happened and how I can prevent this in the future.
Also, should I change all of my passwords(PayPal, Facebook, etc..) from a different PC asap?

item.title: PC Under Attack?
item.dc:creator: @whackatre Whackatre
item.description:
@whackatre wrote:

My internet’s frequent disconnecting apparently causes Loveandpower’s RS to crash. ;D

Read full topic

item.title: PC Under Attack?
item.dc:creator: @mista_pnut mista pnut
item.description:
@mista_pnut wrote:

[quote=“Loveandpower, post:1, topic:456072”]This program is dangerous and self-propagates over a network connection.

It is considered a form of a worm because of it’s nature. Disable your network and remove. If need by try to run malwarebytes in safe mode.[/quote]

I remove it and scan again and it is still there. Any idea of why that would happen?

Read full topic

item.title: PC Under Attack?
item.dc:creator: @kingman002 kingman002
item.description:
@kingman002 wrote:

[quote=“mista pnut, post:1, topic:456060”]Okay, so I was playing runescape when my client randomly crashed, just out of nowhere closed. I instantly reloaded a client and tried to login and couldn’t for 15 minutes. I finally logged in noticed that the last connection wasn’t my IP and all of my possessions were gone, but not long after I logged in my client crashed again.

By this time, I knew something pretty bad was going on. But wait, it gets better…

I opened my Task Manager to see if there were any suspicious processes and I couldn’t find a thing, while looking at my processes, they just all started to end. If I opened a program it would close. It was like someone had total control of my PC and I had hardly any other than opening programs that would be instantly closed until my PC turned off.

So, I hopped straight onto another PC to see if I could figure anything out about what may have happened and I’m clueless. So, could anyone please tell me what has happened and how I can prevent this in the future.

Also, should I change all of my passwords(PayPal, Facebook, etc…) from a different PC asap?[/quote]
You would imagine you would change passwords to stuff like PayPal as they could try and steal your cash.

Read full topic

item.title: PC Under Attack?
item.dc:creator: @Ix_Soulcist_xI Soulcist
item.description:
@Ix_Soulcist_xI wrote:

[quote=“mista pnut, post:3, topic:456060”]McAfee virus scan came up clean & I’m running a scan with Microsoft Security Essentials at the moment.

Are there other free programs that do a good job of searching?

EDIT: Microsoft Security Essentials came up with
Detected items Alert Level Status Recommended Action
Work:Win32/Ainsolt.A Severe Active Quarantine(Other options: remove)[/quote]
Probably would want to delete it then eh?

Read full topic

item.title: PC Under Attack?
item.dc:creator: @mista_pnut mista pnut
item.description:
@mista_pnut wrote:

McAfee virus scan came up clean & I’m running a scan with Microsoft Security Essentials at the moment.

Work:Win32/Ainsolt.A Severe Active Quarantine(Other options: remove)

item.title: PC Under Attack?
item.dc:creator: @Stupit Stu
item.description:
@Stupit wrote:

It’s called a Remote Administration Tool or RAT for short. Disconnect said computer from the internet and run virus scan’s on it. Easy as that. As for your passwords, change them.

Read full topic
